name: ConsumerConfiguration
documentation:
Configuration class that defines how a message consumer behaves during message tracking and handler invocation.

{@code ConsumerConfiguration} is used to fine-tune the behavior of message consumers beyond what is possible with the {@link Consumer} annotation. It supports handler filtering, tracking concurrency, custom interceptors, and more.

Usage: Consumers can be declared programmatically using this configuration object, or generated automatically from {@code @Consumer} annotations on handler classes or packages. @see Consumer @see io.fluxzero.sdk.configuration.FluxzeroBuilder#addConsumerConfiguration

fields.name: batchInterceptors
fields.documentation: Interceptors that are invoked before and after a batch of messages is processed.

fields.name: clientControlledIndex
fields.documentation:
If true, the consumer's position in the log will be controlled by the client (not automatically). Allows handling
 messages manually or out of order.

fields.name: errorHandler
fields.documentation:
Defines how errors during handler invocation are handled. Defaults to logging errors and continuing with other
 messages.

fields.name: exclusive
fields.documentation:
If true (default), ensures this consumer is exclusive — no other consumers with the same name will run
 concurrently.

fields.name: filterMessageTarget
fields.documentation:
If true, only messages that target the current application will be processed. This allows isolating handlers to
 specific applications.

fields.name: flowRegulator
fields.documentation:
Regulates the flow of messages to the consumer to prevent overload. Defaults to {@link NoOpFlowRegulator}, which
 performs no throttling.

fields.name: handlerFilter
fields.documentation:
Optional predicate that determines whether a given handler is included in this consumer.

This is especially useful when combining multiple handler classes or packages and you want to restrict consumption to a subset.

fields.name: handlerInterceptors
fields.documentation: Interceptors that wrap handler execution for additional behavior (e.g. logging, metrics, authorization).

fields.name: ignoreSegment
fields.documentation:
If true, the consumer will ignore the segment assigned to it and process all messages regardless of partitioning.
 Useful for global handlers such as notifications or singletons.

fields.name: maxFetchSize
fields.documentation: Maximum number of messages to fetch per poll from the message log.

fields.name: maxIndexExclusive
fields.documentation: Optional exclusive upper limit for message index (messages with this index or higher will be skipped).

fields.name: maxWaitDuration
fields.documentation: Maximum wait time for polling new messages.

fields.name: minIndex
fields.documentation: Optional minimum index to start processing messages from.

fields.name: name
fields.documentation: Unique name for the consumer. Used for tracking and identifying its state.

fields.name: passive
fields.documentation:
If true, the consumer will passively listen to messages without marking them as consumed. Useful for debug,
 logging, or metrics purposes.

fields.name: purgeDelay
fields.documentation: Optional delay after which previously consumed segments should be purged from memory.

fields.name: singleTracker
fields.documentation: If true, forces a single tracker to be created for this consumer regardless of segment count.

fields.name: storePositionManually
fields.documentation:
Whether this consumer is taking manual control over storing its position in the log.

When {@code true}, the consumer is responsible for explicitly storing its position after processing one or more message batches. This allows for greater control — for example, when handling long-running workflows that span multiple batches, or when committing position should be deferred until post-processing is complete.

When {@code false} (the default), the position is automatically updated after each message batch is processed, ensuring progress is recorded and avoiding reprocessing on restart.

Note: Even with manual position tracking enabled, the consumer will continue to receive "new" messages as long as the tracking process remains active. However, its persisted position will not be updated unless explicitly stored.

fields.name: threads
fields.documentation: Number of concurrent threads to process messages.

fields.name: trackerIdFactory
fields.documentation:
Factory for generating a tracker ID for this consumer. The default implementation appends a random UUID to the
 client ID.

fields.name: typeFilter
fields.documentation:
Optional class name pattern to filter message types. When provided, only messages whose payload matches the type
 name pattern will be processed.

methods.name: configurations
methods.documentation:
Returns a stream of {@code ConsumerConfiguration}s by inspecting the given handler classes and their packages.
 Includes both class-level and package-level {@code @Consumer} annotations.
